Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Offshore Wind Turbines Subjected to Hurricanes: Simulation of Wind-Wave-Structure Interaction and Aerodynamic Load Reduction

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objectives of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project are to investigate the behavior of offshore wind turbines subjected to hurricane loads and to develop novel approaches that can reduce the damage. Specific research activities include: (1) to establish a time-domain analysis procedure that considers interactions of wave, wind, soil, and structure; (2) to study the behavior of wind turbine using the loading consistent with the field observations of hurricanes; (3) to devise a piezoelectric surface actuation mechanism to aerodynamically reduce the wind forces; and (4) to explore the reconfiguration of the structure to reduce the drag forces. The new time-domain formulation of the wind turbine tower will be integrated with the turbine analysis program FAST developed and maintained by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory. Recent field observations of hurricane characteristics will be utilized to define the loading. Wind tunnel testing of scaled models will also be conducted to obtain necessary parameters for numerical simulation, and to quantify the effects of the piezoelectric surface actuation in reducing the drag forces.
Offshore wind farms have enormous energy potential, yet one of the major concerns is vulnerability of wind turbines in hurricanes. The results of this project can reduce risk to wind turbine structures in hurricanes and can contribute to wider adoption of the offshore wind energy. The Principal Investigator will collaborate with the National Renewable Energy Laboratory so that the research outcome is accessible to a wider audience. The research project is integrated with education through involvement of undergraduate and graduate students as well as involvement of underrepresented students through the college's partnership with a minority-serving institution. In order to increase the number of engineers who can work in renewable energy field, college-wide collaboration in renewable energy and the Florida State University (FSU) Office of Distance Learning will be utilized. The outreach of this project will involve high school students in research through the FSU Young Scholars Program. Annual workshops for K-12 teachers will be offered with the help of KidWind. Through these workshops, the teachers will develop teaching modules on wind energy to enhance their science curricula.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Offshore wind farms have enormous energy potential, yet one of the major concerns is vulnerability of wind turbines in hurricanes. Accurate analysis of wind turbine behavior can reduce the uncertainties and contribute to a wider adoption of wind turbines in hurricane-prone regions. This project created new knowledge in behavior of wind turbines subjected to hurricanes. A new formulation was developed to accurately model the effect of fluctuating winds on the wind turbine tower. Wind loading was generated to be consistent with the latest field observations of hurricanes. The modeling of monopile foundation was employed from the literature, and then improved. Finally, the behavior of an offshore wind turbine subjected to hurricanes was analyzed.

In addition to advancing the knowledge in behavior of wind turbines subjected to hurricanes, the second research objective of the project was to explore methods to reduce the aerodynamic forces on wind turbines. For this, wind tunnel testing was conducted for two different ideas. First, the effectiveness of surface patterns in reducing the pressure drag was investigated. Previous studies were under the uniform and laminar flow, whereas our contribution was to study the flow pattern under simulated atmospheric boundary layer winds. Second, actuation of the tower surface using the piezoelectric material was investigated. Unlike many other control methods, this approach preserves the shape of the structure while creating surface vibration using the piezoelectric material.

The educational objectives of the project were to increase the number of engineers ready to work in the wind energy field and to improve public opinion of renewable energy. For wind energy education, a new graduate course on wind energy was created. Due to the multidisciplinary nature of this subject, students from four different departments (civil, electrical, mechanical, and industrial engineering) took the course. In addition, multidisciplinary undergraduate senior design projects were created. High school students were involved in one of the research tasks. The PI took a five-day workshop offered by KidWind, focusing on renewable energy outreach and education for K-12 teachers and students. Annual half-a-day workshop was offered to K-12 teachers, so that the teachers could teach hands-on activities in their classrooms. Other outreach activities were also conducted such as participation in the college open house event.
